headline: Man Utd to hold fresh Michael Carrick talks as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer twist emerges
body: Manchester United are set to hold another round of talks to decide their next interim manager, with Michael Carrick edging closer to current favourite Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. United have opted to appoint a caretaker for the remainder of the season before selecting a permanent replacement for Ruben Amorim.

The Red Devils sacked Amorim on Monday following a run of just three wins in 11 games, but the decision was mainly down to a fallout with the club's director of football Jason Wilcox. Under-18 boss Darren Fletcher led the first team for Wednesday's deflating 2-2 draw away to Burnley and he'll remain in charge when United host Brighton in the FA Cup third round on Sunday.

By then, Wilcox and United CEO Omar Berrada are expected to have interviewed both Carrick and Solskjaer face-to-face. The Guardian report that although Solskjaer is still the slight favourite, Carrick moved closer on Wednesday.

Should Wilcox and Berrada choose Solskjaer, it's understood that Carrick would consider being his assistant once again. Carrick worked under Solskjaer when the Norwegian was in charge of the Red Devils from December 2018 to November 2021.

The five-time Premier League winner was already part of United's first-team coaching setup when Solskjaer took over, initially on an interim basis, in the wake of Jose Mourinho's sacking. The duo were also team-mates at United for the 2006-07 season.

"They put Ryan [Giggs] in charge ten years ago, then Ole took charge and you go back to the old boys. Then you go for a new one, then you go for one more - it's almost like a cycle and a movie that we've all seen before and Groundhog Day.
Who should Man Utd choose - Michael Carrick or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer? Let us know your pick in the comments section.

"Look, what I do think, Ole is someone that absolutely loves the club. He knows the job, he's been in the job. The other names that are being mentioned, obviously, Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy.

"These are really fantastic people, I played with those guys for a lot of years, they love the club intensely. They get the club. But still they're going to come under a lot of pressure in the next four or five months if results don't go their way.
"So look, they have to be ready for that... Whoever's going to get it, out of those three that are being mentioned, I wish them all the best because it's a tough role."

headline: Italian media reach telling verdict as Scott McTominay changes tune at Napoli
body: Scott McTominay appeared unusually dejected as Napoli were held to a draw by Hellas Verona on Wednesday evening. Yet Italian media were unanimous in declaring him the standout performer for Antonio Conte's side.

The midfielder's remarkable Serie A journey since departing Manchester United in the summer of 2024 has been well-documented, with the 29-year-old claiming the league's MVP award last campaign after securing the title. He subsequently added the Italian Super Cup to his collection in late 2025.

His Napoli team are battling to retain their crown this term but encountered a stumbling block at home on Wednesday against 19th-place Hellas Verona. The away side surged to a commanding 2-0 advantage before strikes from McTominay and Giovanni Di Lorenzo rescued a point.

McTominay collected the Man of the Match honour following the final whistle, though his typically cheerful demeanour in Naples was replaced by visible frustration as he accepted the accolade. Nevertheless, Italian media outlets were in complete agreement that he provided the catalyst for Napoli's fightback, despite their failure to secure three points.
The Scottish midfielder's 54th-minute strike ignited Napoli's resurgence on Wednesday, with La Gazzetta dello Sport praising him as the reason they claimed at least one point.

McTominay received a 6.5/10 rating for his contribution to the stalemate and the outlet commented: "He fights like a highlander even on the most difficult days. It was his goal that put Napoli back on their feet."

He was also hailed as one of Napoli's three standout performers on the evening. They continued: "The Azzurri's best were Di Lorenzo, [Leonardo] Spinazzola and McTominay. The visitors had few incompetencies."
Conte's outfit lost crucial ground in their bid for back-to-back league crowns against Hellas Verona, with Corriere dello Sport branding the result as deflating.

They stated: "It was a disappointing performance from the Azzurri, but a source of pride for [Verona manager Paolo] Zanetti's team, who came close to a feat against a team that hasn't lost at home in over a year."

Yet once more, it was McTominay who earned particular acclaim and secured a 7/10 rating for his outstanding display. They continued: "McTominay was the driving force. In a first half where Napoli seemed to have lost their way, he was the last to surrender.
"His header was a manifesto of power and timing. Beyond the goal, he provided a physical presence that frightened Verona and reanimated a Maradona [stadium] frozen by the double disadvantage."
The accolades for McTominay continued flowing, with Tuttosport also awarding him a 7/10 and heaping praise on him for nearly single-handedly rescuing Conte's team from defeat.
"The soul of the revolt," they penned. "In the tactical desert of the first half, he was the only one who tried to shake his team-mates with fierce runs.
"The goal was a reward for his stubbornness: he towered above everyone and reopened a match that seemed cursed. Without his lungs and his charisma, it would have been a nightmare evening for Conte."
Italian media were unanimous in their praise for McTominay on Wednesday night, with La Repubblica hailing him as the "heart" of Conte's squad and a true leader.

"Conte's Napoli saved themselves with nerves and with McTominay, avoiding a home collapse that would have opened a deep crisis," they reported. "The Scotsman confirmed himself as the 'man of providence', capable of transforming crosses into hope."
La Repubblica awarded McTominay a 6.5/10 for his performance, writing: "He is the beating heart of a team that at times seems soulless. In the first half, he wandered in search of his position.

"But in the second half, it was he who provided the spark with an imperial header. It wasn't just the goal. It was the sense of leadership he conveyed to his team-mates when the match seemed already lost."

headline: Darren Fletcher reveals private Benjamin Sesko chat after Ruben Amorim's feelings emerged
body: Darren Fletcher showed Benjamin Sesko footage of his best moments and reassured the Manchester United star "it is coming" before he doubled his goalscoring tally at Burnley.

The Slovenian had only scored twice prior to the clash at Turf Moor on Wednesday night but bagged a brace during the 2-2 draw. He looked far more confident as he led the United line in the first match of the post-Ruben Amorim era.

Fletcher, who is in caretaker charge of the Red Devils, pulled Sesko to one side prior to the game and showed him highlights of the things he was doing right, claiming his team-mates also needed to do their bit and provide him with better service.

Sesko was United's most expensive signing of the summer, joining for £70million from RB Leipzig, but his struggles in the months since have seen him singled out for criticism. But Fletcher now hopes that his exploits in front of goal can serve as a springboard.

He said: "I was so happy for him. I spoke to him yesterday and we presented a video showing his movement and showing his goals, just showing how it is coming and he needs to keep believing and the players need to get more service to him.

"He did that tonight and scored two great goals. A real positive night for Ben. He had other opportunities, a header, another snapshot. The team is disappointed with a point but in terms of a personal level hopefully he can kick on from that now."

On Sesko, Fletcher added: "He needed it massively. I spoke to him before the game and tried to reiterate what a good player he is and how much I've watched him over the years. We got the service in the box from him and it was great movement, made great runs and he took his two goals fantastically."

United spent over £200m on their frontline, bringing in Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo as well as Sesko. It has emerged that Amorim would've preferred to pursue Ollie Watkins ahead of the Slovenian, but ultimately missed out on the Aston Villa forward.

It is understood that Watkins' proven track record in the Premier League was seen as a plus that Sesko didn't have. The 21-year-old has been cited as one of Europe's most exciting forwards and impressed in Leipzig, but by no means hit the ground running when he arrived in Manchester. In his opening weeks Amorim would regularly leave him on the bench before bringing him on for impact.

headline: Man Utd told 'crazy' Ole Gunnar Solskjaer move would be 'ridiculous' as chaotic candidate named
body: Manchester United would be 'crazy' to appoint Ole Gunnar Solskjaer as boss until the end of the season, and should instead look to Roy Keane or Michael Carrick, according to Danny Murphy. The Red Devils are in search of a new boss after they dismissed Ruben Amorim earlier in the week.

Former midfielder Darren Fletcher has been placed in a caretaker role at Old Trafford, with Solskjaer the frontrunner to take over until the end of the season. The club have been in talks with the Norwegian, in addition to Carrick, who is also available after being sacked by Middlesbrough earlier in the season.
Solskjaer was previously in charge of United from 2018 until 2021. The Baby-faced Assassin replaced Jose Mourinho on an interim basis before impressing enough to land the role full-time.

Match of the Day pundit Murphy has been left aghast that Solskjaer could be tasked with steering United in the right direction. The ex-Liverpool and Fulham midfielder believes there are better options.
"Well the Solskjaer one coming back is crazy," Murphy said. "I mean Man United paid him to leave because he ultimately failed and now they're going to pay him to come back?

"I mean it seems ridiculous when you've got options like Michael Carrick, Fletch obviously is a decent coach and then you've got someone like [Roy] Keane, who the fans would love to come back. Ok, some people might think that might be chaotic but he's a leader."

Stephen Warnock was somewhat in agreement. The former Liverpool and Blackburn defender is unsurprised United chiefs might want to wait until the summer given the candidates who could become available, but says he cannot comprehend a move for Solskjaer.

"I think there's a situation now where they obviously thought Amorim leaving the football club was the right decision. Now they know that there's options that are going to become available after the World Cup and there's going to be a decision on a handful of managers," he said.

"Who's going to be there? Tuchel, Ancelotti, Pochettino? There's going to be a lot available so I understand that waiting - I don't understand the Solskjaer one; I don't understand why you go back there."
Fletcher has confirmed he will be in charge for United's next match against Brighton.
"I've spoken to the board, and I'll be in charge for the Brighton game [in the FA Cup ], and then we'll take it from there. It’s one game at a time," he said.

"I'm not so naive as not to know that if a massive offer comes from City and Marc wants to do it, it will happen," Glasner admitted.

headline: Man Utd star singled out by Sky pundit for scathing criticism - 'never wear the shirt again'
body: Former Premier League manager Tim Sherwood has declared that Benjamin Sesko isn't of the calibre required to represent Manchester United, despite the forward netting twice in Wednesday's 2-2 stalemate with Burnley.

Sesko found the back of the net on two occasions in the second period at Turf Moor, giving Darren Fletcher's squad the advantage following Ayden Heaven's earlier own goal. Jaidon Anthony equalised shortly afterwards to secure a point for the hosts.

For Sesko, these were his first goals for United since scoring in the 2-0 victory over Sunderland on October 4. The forward had been sidelined for four matches with a knee problem before enduring a five-game drought.

His opening strike against the Clarets demonstrated classic centre-forward play as he pounced on Bruno Fernandes' through ball, before he went on to clinically finish Patrick Dorgu's delivery in the second period. He nearly completed his maiden hat-trick in England, but ex-United goalkeeper Martin Dubravka thwarted him.

"I think the positive is Sesko scoring two goals," he commented. "Hopefully he gets some confidence from that. He's took six months to turn up at Man United. I am pleased for the lad, he has had a tough run of it.
"I had him off the pitch at half time, never wear a Man United shirt again. I stand by what I say, he's not good enough to play for Man United.
"He's turned up for one game against Burnley who are going to get relegated. Fair play to him, hopefully he gets some confidence and we start seeing something different from him."
Gary Neville commended Sesko after he skilfully redirected Dorgu's cross. "Bingo time for Benjamin Sesko," he declared.
"We've not seen him smile much and his team mates are revelling in it with him.
"He's got in between the centre-backs all night, and he does it again. That's a really good finish. Manchester United have been really good in this second half."

headline: opinionDarren Fletcher gets Man Utd crash course as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer feelings made clear
body: It's difficult to imagine the mild-mannered Darren Fletcher having the hairdryer treatment in his managerial locker. Like his mentor Sir Alex Ferguson once infamously did.
But whatever he said to his Manchester United stars at half time - it almost worked.

As job interviews go, this one couldn't have started much worse for interim boss Fletcher. United found themselves 1-0 down inside the opening 13 minutes to a Burnley side which hadn't won a game since October. But a stunning comeback after the break saw Benjamin Sesko score twice as United threatened to win a winnable game of football. The goals were Sesko's first ones in three months. And this fact alone makes Fletcher some sort of managerial genius!
But Fletcher discovered that old habits can die hard, and was denied a winning start thanks to a thumping equaliser from Clarets substitute Jaidon Anthony.

Speculation is mounting that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick will both return to take charge of the team until the end of the season. Travelling fans were chanting Solskjaer's name inside eight minutes.

Fletcher had admitted taking charge of United, irrespective of how long for, had been 'beyond his wildest dreams'. The Scot had grown up at United, worked under the great Sir Alex Ferguson and played alongside some of the most illustrious names in the club's long history. But all of this counted for nothing on a freezing night at Turf Moor in January.
It was time for Fletcher to show people he could sprinkle some stardust on a team without a sheen. There was a lot of problems to fix. But for the time being, this wasn't rocket science.
All Fletcher had to do was put his players in a system that got the best out of them. So he reverted to a back four.

But it took Fletcher little time to see United go behind, when Bashir Humphreys was allowed to escape the clutches of Casemiro. When he attempted a cross it deflected off the dithering Ayden Heaven, sending the ball looping into the far corner to put the Clarets ahead. Fletcher stood there shaking his head in disbelief.
United were behind to a side which had gone 11 games without a win, and last tasted victory in October. What would Fergie do now? Perhaps Fletcher could have called him on his mobile to find out.

He would have expected a serious response, but somehow the home side made it to the interval ahead. It felt like an equaliser had been coming, but Fletcher still had some serious talking to at half time. And whatever he said worked, because Sesko fired United level five minutes into the second half, before putting them ahead 10 minutes later.
United were on full throttle and threatened a third through Bruno Fernandes, but his shot clipped Martin Dubravka's left hand post.

But United have become masters at making life difficult for themselves. And six minutes after falling behind, Scott Parker's men drew level when Anthony twisted and turned inside the United box, before unleashing an unstoppable effort into the top corner.
It was no more than the home side deserved.

Fletcher was unimpressed and made some changes in the desperate hope of engineering a winning goal. But whatever he tired didn't work - meaning United have now drawn their last three games against rivals either in the bottom three or close to it.

headline: Man Utd can shed £13m in wages if three unhappy players leave after Ruben Amorim exit
body: Manchester United can still shed a reported £13m in wages if three players who were unhappy under Ruben Amorim leave the club. The Daily Mail claims Kobbie Mainoo, Joshua Zirkzee and Manuel Ugarte were all looking to leave Old Trafford in January, had the Portuguese head coach remained in charge.

All three have struggled for regular game time this season and could be handed an Old Trafford lifeline by an interim head coach and their permanent successor. It remains to be seen whether any of the trio will look to force a move away from the club, but United may still look to offload their wages.
The estimated wages of the trio adds up to around £13m, with academy graduate Mainoo the lowest paid at a reported £1m a year, while Ugarte is on an estimated £6.24m and Zirkzee on around £5.2m
Mainoo will be hoping to force his way back into the United set-up under a new head coach, having fallen down the pecking order under Amorim.
He's gone from an unsellable asset and starter for England in the European Championship Final, to the substitutes bench and has not been able to agree a contract extension.
Chelsea and Napoli are two of the clubs reportedly keen on his services, though United fans will be hoping he sticks around.
Ugarte is another who will be hoping to force his way back into the side, with a change in formation potentially handing both midfielders a way back into the XI.
The same can be said for Joshua Zirkzee, though a return to Italy has been heavily speculated throughout the season and an AS Roma transfer chief has addressed recent speculation.
"Naturally, the situation is different after this change of management, there are no contacts in progress, but I wouldn't focus on individual names.
"We know this window is an opportunity to reinforce the squad in an area where we have struggled to convert chances into goals, so we will try to use it.
"We started over the summer with a process of renewal. We knew it would take a while and several different transfer sessions.

"There are things we need to do that are not considered an emergency, but rather an opportunity to take. Don't forget this team had a very strong 2025 of a high level and we'd like to keep that going.
"With so many games close together and players out through injury, international duty, even flu, it might seem to be a weaker squad than usual. However, the team is ready and will step up."

headline: Darren Fletcher makes feelings crystal clear over Man Utd failure at Burnley
body: Darren Fletcher accused Manchester United of blowing two vital points on his first game as interim manager. Fletcher suffered a rollercoaster start to life as caretaker boss on a frustrating night at Turf Moor.

Fletcher took charge following the sacking of Ruben Amorim - and looked to be on course for a win thanks to Benjamin Sesko's second half brace. Sesko's double wiped out Burnley's opener from Bashir Humphreys inside the opening 13 minutes.

But Fletcher's hopes of staging the perfect job interview were ruined by Clarets substitute Jaidon Anthony's equaliser on 66 minutes. And Fletcher was left ruing United's wastefulness in front of goal. United have now failed to beat Wolves, Leeds United and Burnley in their last three outings.

Fletcher said: "We put in a performance that should have won the match. We created a lot of chances. I thought we started slow but improved. We scored two fantastic goals, but there is still a lot to work on.
"It was about them highlighting themselves, showcasing themselves as players. It wasn't perfect but there were a lot of good things. But we have got to score more goals."

Burnley boss Scott Parker said: "What the team demanded of itself was right up there. It's a great reaction from the weekend. We got back to what we need to bring to a game of Premier League football.
"It's a big point for us. A massive point. It showed the character of the team in adversity. We stood up."

headline: Man Utd player ratings vs Burnley as Benjamin Sesko shines but 4/10 star struggles
body: Manchester United's quest for Champions League football took another hit as they were held to a 2-2 draw at Burnley in Darren Fletcher's inaugural match at the helm.

The Red Devils got off to a sluggish start and found themselves trailing after just 13 minutes when Casemiro was outfoxed by Bashir Humphreys' run and Ayden Heaven's feeble attempt to block the cross resulted in an own goal. However, Fletcher's team soon regained control, with two goals from Benjamin Sesko in the opening 15 minutes of the second half seemingly turning the tide. He expertly finished off a Bruno Fernandes pass and a Patrick Dorgu cross.

Yet, inexplicably, United allowed the hosts back into the game. Despite posing little threat in the second half, Jaidon Anthony was given too much space by Lisandro Martinez to turn and curl in an equaliser.
Here's how the players at Turf Moor were rated...
Senne Lammens - 6
His decision to try and anticipate Humphreys' cross wasn't the best, but he was helpless for the second goal. Showed good ball control.
Diogo Dalot - 6
Kept possession well and attempted to push forward in the second half, but failed to make a significant impact. United's narrow play didn't afford him much of the ball.
Ayden Heaven - 5
Turned his back on the cross that led to the own goal when he should have made himself bigger. Showed aggression on the ball at times.
Lisandro Martinez - 5

This was arguably his poorest performance since rejoining the starting line-up. Fired one wild shot and was far too passive against Anthony in the box, allowing the winger ample space to score the equaliser.
Luke Shaw - 7
Made a significant impact in the forward areas, linking well with Dorgu and making intelligent runs, both overlapping and underlapping.
Manuel Ugarte - 6
Advanced quite far up the pitch at times. Despite his two shots being off target, he had a solid game and showed better ball control.
Casemiro - 4
A pale imitation of his earlier season form. He simply watched as Humphreys ran past him for the first goal, was booked and often too slow to react.
Bruno Fernandes - 7
Delivered an excellent pass to set up Sesko's equaliser and was always eager to get on the ball. Showed his creative prowess.
Patrick Dorgu - 7
Currently playing in various positions. It was somewhat surprising to see him on the left, but he gave Kyle Walker a tough time and his cross for Sesko was spot on.
Matheus Cunha - 6
Less influential than in recent weeks. Struggled on the right in the first half and didn't improve much when moved centrally.
Benjamin Sesko - 8
His best performance for the club so far. Had numerous opportunities, held the ball up well, scored two fantastic goals and forced Martin Dúbravka into another good save with a fine header.
Leny Yoro - 6
Another change in central defence. Performed adequately.
Mason Mount - 6
Failed to match Fernandes' impact.
Kobbie Mainoo - 6
Entered the game in a deep position and tried to get involved.
Joshua Zirkzee - 6
Had a couple of half chances but couldn't convert them
Shea Lacey - 7
Unlucky not to score following a brilliant piece of play.

headline: Bruno Fernandes problem rears its head as Man Utd fall short at Burnley - 5 talking points
body: Ruben Amorim is gone, but Manchester United's failings remain as caretaker boss Darren Fletcher saw his side fail to win at Burnley.

Benjamin Sesko scored twice for the Red Devils early in the second half and, in truth, should have won this game for the visitors, but Jaidon Anthony's fine 66th minute strike earned Burnley a share of the spoils.

Sesko's double - two very impressive finishes - wiped out Burnley's opener from Bashir Humphreys inside the opening 13 minutes, his cross deflecting off Ayden Heaven and looping over Senne Lammens into the net. Fletcher would have been cursing his luck.

Shea Lacey almost won it late in the day, a sumptuous 25-yarder hitting Martin Dubravka's crossbar. But in truth, United lacked the craft and quality required to win here, particularly when a 70 percent fit Bruno Fernandes had departed the scene on the hour mark.
Here are five talking points from Turf Moor...
One man who has been getting a fair bit of credit for his recent performances has been young centre-back Ayden Heaven.

Despite the team’s recent inconsistencies, he has impressed at the heart of a defence shorn of Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire, with Lisandro Martinez easing his way back and Leny Yoro having been more out than in lately.
But his role in Burnley ’s opener after 12 minutes deserves scrutiny because, frankly, it wasn’t good enough.

It wasn’t that he hadn’t sensed the danger as the Clarets went down the left side. It’s that he was far too sluggish in getting himself over to it. He knew the run hadn’t been tracked, that Dalot was caught higher up. But he ambled out rather than sprinting and getting close. Had he done that, then he wouldn’t have suffered the misfortune of deflecting the cross into his own net.

It was simple, basic defending. He didn’t do it and United were punished. To add to the ignominy, Heaven becomes the youngest United player to score a Premier League own goal, aged 19 years and 107 days.
It was always going to happen wasn't it. The moment Ruben Amorim was out the door, that 3-4-3 formation he was wedded to was going with him. And so it did.
But a return to a back four for one of Fergie's favourite sons didn't stop United from suffering a frustrating evening against a side who haven't won since October.
Bruno Fernandes is Manchester United's best player. He is also still only at the club thanks to Ruben Amorim.

Thankfully for United fans, the club's former head coach made clear to his captain last summer that he was crucial to his plans and shouldn't go to Saudi Arabia - at a time when the player felt the club hierarchy were happy to see him go.

United remain over-reliant on their captain. He wasn't fully fit here, but just over 24 hours after being out at a coffee shop with Amorim's No.2 - in what by all accounts was a pretty sorrowful farewell - gave his caretaker boss 60 minutes and produced an outstanding slide-rule pass to get Sesko in behind to fire United level.

Whoever is the next manager - be it permanent or interim - Fernandes remains the United player who is a top-level difference maker. But Amorim's exit and the spectre of Saudi means his long-term future is very much back under the microscope.
Which is a big problem. Because when he isn't on the pitch, United lose their way.
Which they did here. On the 60 minute mark, Fernandes was substituted. Six minutes later, Burnley were level.

But that isn't strictly true. Yes, for the first 15 minutes of the second half, United had been dominant, scoring twice and going ahead. But the moment Fernandes departed the scene - having just hit the post - the team visibly shrunk. Suddenly, players didn't look comfortable taking possession and trying to dominate a game against the side in 19th place.

And this didn't take time to happen. This happened within seconds. The home side were suddenly emboldened as United dropped closer to their own goal, the visitors were sloppy near their own box again - this time Lisandro Martinez not closing down the way he should - and Anthony curled an wonderful strike into the top corner.

You have to wonder whether those United chiefs - who may or may not have been in the directors' box at Turf Moor - still think they can do without Fernandes. Because this period of this game, like the entirety of the dismal home draw with Wolves, highlighted that this team cannot.

Manchester United's giant striker scored twice, should have had more and showed with his movement, speed and quick feet that he can be a real menace to opposing defences. His two finishes for his goals were brilliant. Both taken clinically, both finishes that oozed class.

But they were by no means the only chances the former RB Leipzig hitman had. In fact he had more shots on target (7) than any other player has managed in a Premier League game this term. The problem was the standard of his shooting on those other chances - some of which weren't anything like as difficult as his second - left a hell of a lot to be desired.
A little it more composure and he would have had his hat-trick.

headline: Man Utd supporters send damning four-word message to owners after Ruben Amorim sacking
body: Manchester United fans have sent a message to Sir Jim Ratcliffe ahead of this evening's Premier League clash at Burnley following the sacking of Ruben Amorim.
Amorim left the club on Monday morning, less than 24 hours after the 1-1 draw at Leeds United. The decision came away the Portuguese unleashed a jaw-dropping rant in his post-match press conference.

Darren Fletcher was placed in interim charge for the game at Turf Moor, with the club considering their options to appointing a temporary head coach until the end of the season. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick are the leading candidates.
However, the travelling fans at Burnley have made their feelings known on the situation. A banner that read: "JIM CAN'T FIX THIS" was spotted from the away end prior to kick-off.

Jason Wilcox and Omar Berrada have also come under scrutiny this week. It's understood that the former held a meeting Amorim last week to discuss tactics, but it concluded with the pair unable to agree.

Ahead of the game, it was revealed that Solskjaer and Carrick had both held further talks with the United board. Solskjaer is the favourite to take over for the remainder of the current campaign after previously impressing in the dugout at Old Trafford.

The Norwegian replaced Jose Mourinho in 2018 and won 14 of his 19 games in interim charge before getting the job permanently. He led the club to a top two finish and successive top four finishes, but was sacked in November 2021.
Solskjaer will return to Norway tomorrow from his Cheshire home, to attend the funeral of a close friend. But it's understood he could be appointed before the start of next week.

A permanent replacement is expected to come in at the end of the season. Thomas Tuchel, who he tried to land before appointing Amorim in November 2024, remains high on his wish-list. Others under consideration include Carlo Ancelotti and Mauricio Pochettino.

headline: Jose Mourinho could help Ruben Amorim land immediate return after Man Utd sacking
body: Following his Manchester United dismissal, Ruben Amorim could be in "pole position" to take charge at Benfica - should Jose Mourinho get the axe, it has been claimed.

Current Benfica boss Mourinho is thought to be "increasingly vulnerable" in his role as his team trail league leaders Porto by 10 points in the Primeira Liga. The 62-year-old took over from Bruno Lage at the Estadio da Luz last September and has since secured 14 victories from his 22 games at the helm.

Should Benfica decide to pull the trigger and dismiss Mourinho, Amorim could emerge as a candidate for consideration, according to The Daily Mail. The former Sporting CP boss still has support at Benfica - having turned out 154 times for the club during his playing days, claiming three Primeira Liga times and one Taca de Portugal triumph.
Back in September, following a meal with Amorim, Benfica legend Nuno Gomes predicted that the now former United manager would eventually lead the club.
However, such an appointment would enrage Sporting supporters; the club where Amorim spent nearly five years in the dugout before his departure to United in November 2024.

Amorim achieved legendary status at Sporting after delivering their first Primeira Liga championship in 19 years during the 2020/21 campaign. He secured his second Portuguese title in 2023/24 and also claimed the Taca da Liga on two occasions.
It was at Sporting where Amorim established himself as one of Europe's top young managers, leading to United snapping him up 14 months ago after Erik ten Hag was shown the door.

Rumours in September suggested that Benfica were monitoring Amorim's situation at United as he faced scrutiny for a sluggish start to the season. However, the Lisbon outfit instead opted to lure Mourinho back to Portugal, two decades after he departed Porto for Chelsea.

Amorim, on the other hand, managed to hold onto his position at United for another four months before the Old Trafford heavyweights decided to dismiss the 40-year-old on Monday, following Sunday's 1-1 stalemate with rivals Leeds. Darren Fletcher has been appointed as interim manager for Wednesday's journey to Burnley, with Jonny Evans named as his deputy.

Ahead of United's clash with the Clarets, Fletcher said: "Surreal. It's an amazing honour to lead a Manchester United team especially as it was not in my wildest dreams that would be something which could potentially happen.
"To lead out the team is an amazing honour and something I'm really proud to do, but not in the circumstances I expected it to happy so that is something which doesn't sit quite easy with me.
"But, I have just got to think I have a job to do and I just have to lead the team tomorrow and think of the great honour and pride in doing that."

Fletcher and Evans are also set to lead the team against Brighton in the FA Cup on Sunday, before United then gear up to appoint a temporary manager until the summer. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has surfaced as a leading contender to fill that role for the rest of the season.

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer given green light to make Manchester United return
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is in pole position to return to Manchester United as interim manager.

Ruud van Nistelrooy and Michael Carrick have also been in contention to replace the sacked Ruben Amorim on an interim basis. But Van Nistelrooy has been ruled out, while Carrick has fallen behind Solskjaer in the running to take charge, but could still be offered a role alongside Solskjaer. Solskjaer held talks with club bosses on Tuesday and is said to have impressed CEO Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox.

Solskjaer will return to Norway tomorrow from his Cheshire home, to attend the funeral of a close friend. But it's understood he could be appointed before the start of next week. Darren Fletcher is the current interim boss and took charge of United's game at Burnley on Wednesday night.
But it's believed United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe still wants to look elsewhere for a permanent replacement for Amorim and will wait until the summer.
Thomas Tuchel, who he tried to land before appointing Amorim in November 2024, remains high on his wish-list. Others under consideration include Carlo Ancelotti and Mauricio Pochettino.
Former United striker Solskjaer took temporary charge of the team in December 2018 when Jose Mourinho was sacked.
He landed the job on a permanent basis and went on to manage United for almost three years.

The 52-year-old, who lasted less than six months as manager of Besiktas, is desperate to make an emotional return to Old Trafford for a second spell in charge, deciding to cut short what he had been planning would be an extended break from the game.
But his potential return has sparked widespread criticism on social media, with supporters accusing the club of looking backwards and being too obsessed with the past.

headline: Gary Neville makes Ole Gunnar Solskjaer Man Utd return feelings clear with Liverpool point
body: Ex-Manchester United captain Gary Neville says his old club are repeating the same errors Liverpool made before Jurgen Klopp arrived, with them caught in an endless loop of appointing and sacking managers. United showed Ruben Amorim the door earlier this week after the weekend's draw with rivals Leeds - and they are now searching for a new head coach at Old Trafford.

Darren Fletcher has stepped in temporarily to oversee tonight's match against Burnley, while the Red Devils are reportedly in discussion with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick over possible comebacks to the hot-seat.

Neville, who was mentioned in Amorim's parting blast at the club, says he wouldn't rule out Solskjaer getting the role permanently if he can revive United's fortunes, but the pundit drew a compelling parallel with United's bitter rivals Liverpool.

"You almost go through cycles whereby, and United have done this for 12 years now. They put Ryan [Giggs] in charge ten years ago, then Ole [Gunnar Solskjaer] took charge and you go back to the old boys.
"Then you go for a new one, then you go for one more - it's almost like a cycle and a movie that we've all seen before and Groundhog Day.
"Look, what I do think, Ole is someone that absolutely loves the club. He knows the job, he's been in the job.

"The other names that are being mentioned, obviously, Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy. These are really fantastic people, I played with those guys for a lot of years, they love the club intensely.

"They get the club. But still they're going to come under a lot of pressure in the next four or five months if results don't go their way. So look, they have to be ready for that... Whoever's going to get it, out of those three that are being mentioned, I wish them all the best because it's a tough role."
Fletcher, who previously worked as first-team coach under former manager Erik ten Hag, has also held the role of technical director at United.

This marks his first venture into management and, as a result, the Old Trafford giants are contemplating bringing in a more experienced interim boss until the end of the season, with Solskjaer and Carrick both in the frame.

When asked about a potential return to United prior to Amorim's appointment as head coach, Solskjaer admitted during a Q&A at the Oslo Business Forum that he would answer the call if it came his way again.
"If the family [United] asks, I would say yes every day of the week," he said. "It feels wrong to talk about jobs other people have, but I would say yes, of course."

headline: Man Utd face uncomfortable truth with Ruben Amorim replacement verdict
body: Darren Fletcher has stepped in as interim manager for United and he will be in the dugout for Wednesday night's Premier League clash against Burnley at Turf Moor.

Speculation is, meanwhile, already mounting that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer could make a sensational return to United on an interim basis until the summer, while the club search for a permanent replacement.

Glasner's name has been mentioned in reports as a potential candidate for the United hot-seat in recent days, though the Crystal Palace boss was quick to dismiss such talk when quizzed at a press conference.
Cole, meanwhile, has expressed his sympathy for Amorim following his recent Old Trafford exit.

"It was the right time," Cole said in an interview with Paddy Power. "When he came into the club - and everyone was expecting him to just breeze in and waltz it like he did at [Sporting] Lisbon - I was never fully on board with that.
"The ownership need to have a look at themselves, as well. You've had Dave Brailsford in there, but the club has been a mess for so many years now and I do feel sorry for Ruben [Amorim]."

Cole also elaborated on why he believes Glasner could be an ideal replacement for Amorim at United, citing the Austrian's current contract situation at Selhurst Park as a potential advantage for the Red Devils.
"Well, it's a similar situation with Chelsea, you aren't looking at the top boys anymore," Cole said.

"You aren't shopping there. So Crystal Palace fans won't like me for saying this, but letting your manager go down to six months left on his contract is worrying for them, because I think Oliver Glasner could be someone that could get Manchester United back on track if the people above him let him do his job.
"Is there a system in place behind the scenes? Are they going to work together?
"Can they work together? What's that relationship like long-term?
"You can have the best manager in the world and the best director of football in the world - and the best sports Scientists - but if they don't work together, then it can't work."

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer completely scraps management return plan after Man Utd twist
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was planning to continue his break from management until Manchester United came calling. Solskjaer, 52, has emerged as a leading contender to temporarily replace Ruben Amorim in the Old Trafford dugout.

The Norwegian would take the job on an interim basis, just as he did seven years ago before earning the role permanently. United want to wait until the summer to decide on a permanent successor to Amorim, who was sacked by the hierarchy on Monday.

Darren Fletcher has been put in charge for Wednesday's trip to Burnley, the same day Solskjaer met with the club's top brass to discuss the role, as he did on Tuesday. Fellow ex-United player and club legend Michael Carrick did the same and it can't be ruled that the pair will team up, having worked together for the entirety of Solskjaer's three-year reign which ended in November 2021.

Until he was appointed Besiktas manager last January, Solskjaer had been off the touchline since leaving Old Trafford. The former United striker, who made 366 appearances for the club, had previously been working for UEFA as a technical observer.

But his time at Besiktas came to an end in August when the Turkish club failed to qualify for Conference League, losing to Lausanne-Sport - coincidentally owned by United's co-owners, INEOS - in the play-offs. Following his dismissal, Solskjaer didn't have plans to make an imminent to return to management.

But as reported by the Sun, United's call has changed everything. Solskjaer, who recently relocated to Cheshire, is said to have told a confidant last week that he wasn't looking to get back into management any time soon.

However, the 52-year-old is keen on the idea of returning to the United hot seat. Solskjaer and his wife, Silje, are living in Cheshire while their children remain back home in Norway. Their oldest son, Noah, plays for Stjordals-Blink while daughter Karna plays for Aalesunds.

In 2014, Solskjaer confirmed that he'd be willing to return to United. "If the family [United] asks, I would say yes every day of the week," he told a Q&A at the Oslo Business Forum. "It feels wrong to talk about jobs that other people have now, but I would say yes, of course."

After taking over from Jose Mourinho in December 2018, Solskjaer led the Red Devils to an incredible run of form. United won 14 of their 17 games while Solskjaer was interim manager, and he oversaw sixth, third and second-place finishes after being made permanent boss before he was axed following a poor start to the 2021-22 season.

headline: Man Utd star proved Ole Gunnar Solskjaer wrong after damning blunt verdict overheard
body: As speculation mounts around a potential Old Trafford comeback for Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, focus has shifted to the players who know the Norwegian from his previous spell in the dugout. One such player, Diogo Dalot, has already delivered a telling response to Solskjaer's private doubts and now has an opportunity to display his progress under recent managers.

Dalot arrived at the club during summer 2018, during what would prove to be Jose Mourinho's final transfer window at the helm before his dismissal in December of that year. Mourinho's sacking led to Solskjaer's appointment, initially on a temporary basis, with Dalot seeing his opportunities limited.

After securing the role permanently, Solskjaer received transfer backing and amongst his earliest decisions was spending £50million on new right-back Aaron Wan-Bissaka. This hardly demonstrated faith in Dalot, who subsequently spent more than one spell out through injury throughout the 2019/20 campaign and managed just four Premier League outings in his second United season.

Sources at the time suggested Solskjaer's worry was that Dalot "couldn't defend," with those comments later making it out into the open after being overheard. On one notable occasion, Solskjaer was willing to give Timothy Fosu-Mensah a first United start in three years rather than trust Dalot against Crystal Palace in July 2020.

Dalot spent the 2020/21 season on loan at AC Milan, even facing his parent club United in the Europa League last 16. He never abandoned hope of reviving his Old Trafford prospects, though, despite celebrating Simon Kjaer's late equaliser for the Italian side in that European clash.

The defender was primarily used as a substitute at the beginning of the 2021/22 campaign but earned starting opportunities after Solskjaer was dismissed and Ralf Rangnick assumed interim control. By the conclusion of that season, United were willing to entertain offers for Wan-Bissaka but not for Dalot, who had become a more valuable part of the squad.

"I feel like I'm a Man United player," the full-back said during United's pre-season tour of Australia that summer. "But obviously work every single day to play. I wanna be ready for the manager, for the club, and every time he needs me I'm gonna be there."

Erik ten Hag took over after Rangnick's interim spell, with the Dutch manager maintaining confidence in Dalot before fellow full-back Wan-Bissaka was sold to West Ham in 2024. Ruben Amorim was equally impressed by the defender, who made a 150th Premier League outing earlier this season.

Sporadic doubts about Dalot's defensive capabilities have persisted, though not enough to seriously threaten his position in the side. That blend of defensive solidity and attacking threat seemed to impress Amorim, who was willing to deploy him on both flanks in his wing-back formation.

Dalot's next challenge will come if, as has been suggested, Solskjaer makes his return to Old Trafford. He made a mere 10 Premier League starts under the Norwegian across nearly three years, including one campaign away on loan, yet he has made considerable progress since then and persuaded multiple United managers that he offers significant value as a full-back - or wing-back - on either side.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Ruben Amorim exit leads to complication as Kobbie Mainoo update emerges
body: Amid Ruben Amorim's sacking, the potential return of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and a packed January schedule, Manchester United also have a transfer window to negotiate. Amorim was shown the door on Monday after falling out with sporting director Jason Wilcox.

Darren Fletcher is taking charge of the team for Wednesday's league game at Burnley and potentially for Sunday's FA Cup third round tie with Brighton, unless a longer-term interim boss has been installed by then. United have held talks with Solskjaer and Michael Carrick about returning to Old Trafford, potentially in tandem until the end of the season.

But that doesn't mean there won't be comings and goings on the transfers front this month as United strive to stay in the race for a Champions League spot. Here's a round-up of the latest transfer news…
The future of Joshua Zirkzee is up in the air following the departure of Amorim. The out-of-favour striker is wanted by Roma on loan.

Amorim was open to letting the Dutchman go and talks have taken place between the two clubs. However, Roma director Ricky Massara has revealed the landscape has changed in light of this week's events at Old Trafford.

Massara told Sky Sport Italia: "He is a Manchester United centre-forward liked by many clubs, not just us. Naturally, the situation is different after this change of management; there are no contacts in progress, but I wouldn’t focus on individual names.
"We know this window is an opportunity to reinforce the squad in an area where we have struggled to convert chances into goals, so we will try to use it."

Another player whose future could be affected by Amorim's departure is Kobbie Mainoo. The England midfielder was seemingly not rated by the now former head coach and there has been speculation that he could join Scott McTominay at Napoli.
However, the BBC reports that the Serie A club believe their chances of signing Mainoo are receding, while no talks are planned between the player and United officials.

And if Fletcher and then Solskjaer - or whoever steps into the breach - switches to a flat back four, Mainoo could be given a fresh start at United, with an extra an extra space available in midfield.
Mainoo is in contention to play against Burnley after returning to training on Tuesday. He has been out since the 4-4 draw with Bournemouth due to injury.

headline: MARSHALL: Man United striker Benjamin Sesko made his point to Ruben Amorim thanks to Darren Fletcher chat
body: When Ruben Amorim offered up some mild criticism of Benjamin Sesko earlier this season, as the £73million striker tried to settle into life at Old Trafford, it again set alarm bells ringing amongst Manchester United officials. Amorim had wanted United to sign the more experienced Ollie Watkins, who also came with proven Premier League pedigree, rather than raid RB Leipzig for 22-year-old Sesko, who came with a glowing reputation from director of recruitment Christopher Vivell.

When the Slovenian struggled in the first few months at United, Amorim admitted he was finding the search for form hard, suggested he was taking criticism to heart and said he was a "control freak". United officials were bemused by what he wanted to get from the comments.

After his final game in charge at Leeds on Sunday, Amorim was offering a more nuanced view of the only natural striker in his squad, but the bare facts said it all: Sesko had just two goals in 17 appearances under the Portuguese head coach.

He doubled that tally in 90 minutes under Darren Fletcher. Jason Wilcox looked sheepish in the stands all night, with his own role as director of football in the spotlight, but this was a good night for those who backed the decision to sign Sesko over Watkins.

His two goals were superbly taken and he had eight shots in total. It was by some distance his best performance in a United shirt and it came a day after a heart-to-heart with Fletcher. The 41-year-old Scot sat the striker down at Carrington on Tuesday and boosted his confidence with a video that showed his strengths.
He highlighted his movement and reassured him that he was on the right path. A day later he scored twice after making the right runs and getting on the same wavelength as his teammates.

"I sat down with him yesterday and showed him some videos of his movement and how the opportunities are going to come, to just keep believing, keep making the runs," said Fletcher. "The rest of the team have to look for him more as well.

"Like with all strikers, once you get that first goal, it builds your confidence, and hopefully they start flooding in from there. I think everyone can see his qualities. I thought he was fantastic tonight. I thought he led the line really well and he maybe could have gone on and had a hat-trick as well.
"He had a few other opportunities there, another snapshot. It's a real positive night for him and definitely probably the biggest positive from the night really is his two goals."

headline: MARSHALL: What Darren Fletcher told Shea Lacey before stunning Manchester United cameo
body: Darren Fletcher has backed Shea Lacey to play a "big part" in Manchester United's future after the 18-year-old's impressive cameo at Turf Moor in Fletcher's first game in charge. The 18-year-old came on with six minutes to go against Burnley and hit the crossbar with one superb strike before sending another shot from range fizzing just wide of the post.

It was Lacey's second appearance for the first team and the first sign of the talent that has marked him out as one to watch within the academy. Fletcher showed faith in throwing him on as United chased a winner and the youngster almost delivered.

"I said to him, stay wide and go and do what you do, and he did that," said Fletcher. "I know he's gonna make an impact. I know he's creative. He's got goals in him. He's exciting, he's direct, he's fearless, and he hit the crossbar, and he had another shot, so he had a really bright game.

"I'm pleased for him because there have been a lot of injuries in recent years, and he's not really got going with his momentum, but we know the talent that he's got, and he'll be a big part of Manchester United's future. I've no doubts about that."

Lacey's efforts were part of a much better attacking display from United, who had 30 shots against the Clarets. They hit the woodwork twice, had two cleared off the line and saw a Lisandro Martinez goal controversially disallowed for a foul.
Fletcher had told his players to go out and entertain, and he was pleased to see United produce a much better attacking display.

"It was about them to be proactive, to attack, to go and highlight themselves, go and showcase the abilities they have as individuals and as players and be really front-foot, proactive, exciting," he said. "They were the challenges that we put towards them and they did that.

"I think, as I said, it wasn't perfect, but there was lots of good things within that. I think if we look back on that game, barring probably the start and then after we went 2-1 up, I think the rest of the game is pretty much total domination and creating lots of chances.
"We probably look at and are disappointed we've not scored more goals because we've got to score more goals when you create that many chances."

headline: RAILSTON: Darren Fletcher gesture to Benjamin Sesko spoke volumes in Manchester United vs Burnley
body: Manchester United drew 2-2 with Burnley in the Premier League on Wednesday. Burnley drew first blood at Turf Moor, taking the lead thanks to a deflected strike which was marked as an own-goal from Ayden Heaven.

Darren Fletcher did not look pleased, but United came out swinging at the start of the second half, and Benjamin Sesko scored twice in relatively quick succession to make it 2-1. However, Burnley drew level thanks to a great strike from Jaidon Anthony, which ensured the points were shared.
Here are the talking points and moments you might have missed from the game:
The anti-Ratcliffe banner

A banner reading 'Jim can't fix this' was unfurled before the game, implying Sir Jim Ratcliffe doesn't have what it takes to turn the club around. The banner was in response to a tumultuous week, which saw Ruben Amorim sacked, Fletcher hired as interim boss, and talks opened with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer over a possible return.

Ratcliffe bemoaned the mistakes of the previous regime when he took control of football operations at Old Trafford, but the Ineos team have created a mess themselves. Omar Berrada oversaw the appointment of Amorim, a coach wedded to playing with five at the back, and Jason Wilcox interfered with the team's tactics, which is a red flag from a director of football.

United sources insisted there had been no power struggle when Amorim's sacking was confirmed, but it was impossible to pull the wool over fans' eyes following his final press conference. Berrada and Wilcox were at Turf Moor and they were both spotted shaking their heads when Burnley opened the scoring. United fans have been shaking their heads at the pair in the last few days.
Thumbs up for Sesko

Sesko was unfortunate not to score in the first half when he sent an outstanding header goal-bound from the edge of the box. The header had to be perfect to have a chance of going in from that distance - and Sesko was just denied by a beautiful save from former United loanee Martin Dubravka.

The Slovenia international looked in the mood from the first whistle, a stark contrast to last weekend against Leeds, and he received a big thumbs up from Fletcher when he equalised - the interim boss clearly knows how crucial Sesko could be in United's push for a European spot. Sesko's second goal was even better. The cross into the box was wonderful, but he still had plenty to do and finished with the kind of ruthlessness that fans doubted he had in his locker.

Patrick Dorgu was responsible for the assist and sprinted to Sesko, who had a huge smile on his face as his teammates celebrated with him. Just last week, Sesko's teammates had their hands on their heads as he sent a potential match-winner wide of the post in the final 20 minutes against Leeds.

Sesko scored as many Premier League goals against Burnley as he'd managed in his first four months in Manchester. Everyone is hoping Sesko's brace in Lancashire signals the beginning of a purple patch.
Huge cheer for Lacey

There was a huge cheer from the away section when Fletcher introduced Shea Lacey for Manuel Ugarte for the final seven minutes of the game. Amorim frustrated fans by regularly bringing on centre-backs in the closing stages of matches, so it was refreshing to see an attacking substitution instead.
Amorim handed Lacey his debut at Villa Park last month. The 18-year-old's first appearance could have come sooner, though, as he'd been knocking on the door for months before his senior bow.

Lacey showed what he can do when smacking the crossbar from the edge of the box just minutes after coming on at Turf Moor. The attacking change from Fletcher was inches away from being a masterstroke.
Fletcher's classy arrival

Fletcher arrived at Turf Moor dressed in a Paul Smith club suit, continuing the trend of former United players-turned caretaker managers wearing a suit and tie on the touchline. The outfit choice comes from playing under Sir Alex Ferguson, who believed United representatives should dress smartly.

The 41-year-old asked Ferguson for his 'blessing' to manage United against Burnley, and he carried himself with class at the pre-match press conference, shaking the hands of journalists. Fletcher should have his head held high if Burnley is the only league game he oversees as interim boss. He behaved like a United manager should before and after the clash at Turf Moor - which counts for something.
Solskjaer and Carrick chants

It took just eight minutes for the away section to begin a rendition of 'you are my Solskjaer, my Ole Solskjaer', which felt like a seal of approval for the Norwegian's increasingly likely return. Solskjaer left on good terms in 2021, despite being booed after his final game in charge against Watford, and the club's press release announcing his sacking said: "He will forever be welcome back."

The 52-year-old will always be popular among fans due to his playing career, but some supporters have mixed feelings about a possible return. Those reservations are merited. The end of Solskjaer's tenure should not be forgotten, although there were positives from his stint.

Carrick was part of Solskjaer's backroom staff, and he is also in contention for the job. The away fans gave Carrick their approval by signing: "He's Carrick, you know, you'll never believe he's not Scholes."
It remains to be seen who will be given the interim job for the remainder of the season.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United player ratings vs Burnley as Benjamin Sesko excellent but one 4/10
body: Manchester United suffered another setback in the race for Champions League football as they were held to a 2-2 draw at Burnley in Darren Fletcher's first game in charge. United started slowly and went behind after 13 minutes. Casemiro was caught out by Bashir Humphreys' run and Ayden Heaven's weak attempt at blocking the cross saw the ball loop in off the centre-back.

Fletcher's side soon took control and two Benjamin Sesko goals in the first 15 minutes of the second half looked to have turned it around. He finished smartly from a Bruno Fernandes pass and Patrick Dorgu cross. Somehow, United let the hosts back into it. They had barely threatened in the second half when Lisandro Martinez let Jaidon Anthony turn and deliver a curling finish.
Here are how the players rated at Turf Moor:
Senne Lammens: Decision to try and read the cross from Humphreys not a good one but powerless with the second goal. Good with the ball at his feet. 6
Diogo Dalot: Tidy in possession and tried to get forward in the second half, but didn't have much of an impact. United's narrow approach didn't get him much of the ball. 6
Ayden Heaven: Turned away from the cross that saw the ball loop in off him, when he should have made himself bigger. Aggressive on the ball at times. 5
Lisandro Martinez: His weakest game since his return to the side. One wild shot and way too passive against Anthony in the area, giving the winger too much space to equalise. 5
Luke Shaw: Got forward well and had an impact in that area. Linked well with Dorgu and made some clever runs, both overlapping and underlapping. 7
Manuel Ugarte: Got quite far forward at times, and although his two shots at goal were wayward, he had a solid game and was better with the ball. 6
Casemiro: A shadow of the player who had done so well earlier in the season. Just watched Humphreys run off him for the first goal, was booked and just too slow to react at times. 4
Bruno Fernandes: Picked a brilliant pass to create the equaliser for Sesko and wanted as much of the ball as he could get. Looked a creative force. 7
Patrick Dorgu: Playing everywhere at the moment. Something of a surprise to see him on the left but gave Kyle Walker a hard time and his cross was perfect for Sesko. 7
Matheus Cunha: Quieter than he has been in recent weeks. Struggled on the right in the first half and didn't improve much for being moved centrally. 6
Benjamin Sesko: His best game for the club. Had plenty of chances, held the ball up well, took his two goals brilliantly and forced Martin Dúbravka into another good save with a fine header. 8
Substitutes
Leny Yoro: Another centre-half change. Did fine. 6
Mason Mount: Struggled to match the impact of Fernandes. 6
Kobbie Mainoo: Came on in a deep area and tried to get on the ball. 6
Joshua Zirkzee: Couple of half chances but couldn't take them. 6
Shea Lacey: So unlucky not to score with a brilliant piece of play. 7
Subs not used: Bayindir, Maguire, Malacia, J. Fletcher

headline: RAILSTON: Benjamin Sesko makes admission over Ruben Amorim sacking at Manchester United - 'Never easy'
body: Benjamin Sesko thinks it's time for Manchester United to "stand up as a group" following Ruben Amorim's sacking. United announced on Monday that Amorim had been sacked after 14 months in charge.
Amorim departed amid rising tensions with the Old Trafford board. Darren Fletcher was in interim charge against Burnley on Wednesday night and was forced to settle for a point.

Speaking about his brace, Sesko added: "It’s important for the team that I can help them. It’s my job. It’s important to commit to the chances, as we were creating lots of chances. We just have to keep pushing in those situations."
In a separate interview with the BBC, he said: "It helps me with my confidence but also to be part of a team, which for me is the most important, to help the team in every single situation.
"It's been tough but now I finally did it and I'm happy I could help the team, this is the most important for me and now it's just up to me and up to us to keep going like that.
"I think the goal happens with the movements. This was really important too because I know I have great players beside me, it's just up to me to make good movement at the right time."

Sesko admitted the goals would give him confidence. "Definitely a lot, especially because, as a striker, and like all the strikers, I think it's important to have a great game and score some goals. Even more important now is I have more confidence than before. Now it's up to me and the team to keep pushing," he explained.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United away end made their feelings clear vs Burnley with chants and banners
body: On the eve of this game, Darren Fletcher admitted leading out a Manchester United team had been beyond his wildest dreams. Watching them draw 2-2 despite only allowing Burnley one shot on target was beyond his worst nightmares.

Quite how United didn't win this game will haunt Fletcher in his dreams for a long time to come. Especially if it ends up being his only game in charge. They bossed Burnley and played some enterprising football at times. Benjamin Sesko scored twice in his best performance for the club, and 18-year-old Shea Lacey hit the bar late on with a stunning individual effort. They were among the 30 shots Fletcher's side had. Burnley managed seven but somehow escaped with a point.

The manner of the two sloppy goals United conceded will infuriate Fletcher, who knows all about the standards expected at this club. Passive defending allowed the Clarets to carry out two successful raids on United's goal, while at the other end Martin Dubravka was busy and the woodwork was on Burnley's side as well.

Whatever happens over the next few days, this will almost certainly be Fletcher's one and only Premier League game in charge. He will hand the reins on with United in seventh, but this felt like a missed opportunity to take a firmer grip in the race for European football, and ideally a spot in the Champions League.

But then that is the story of United's last month. In the space of 35 days they have played five of the bottom six and won none of them. If the passports ended up staying in the draw next season, then the inquest won't take long to work out where it all went wrong.

Those United fans in the Cricket Field Stand at Turf Moor will be desperate to get back to the continent and they felt like a barometer of the feeling around the club after a tumultuous week. As Jason Wilcox and Omar Berrada took their seats in the directors' box they would have glanced at the away end to see a banner reading 'Jim Can't Fix This'. Sir Jim Ratcliffe's time in charge at Old Trafford has been messy and full of mistakes and it feels like the jury is ready to deliver its verdict.

Ratcliffe has making up to do with those United fans who have lost faith in his ability to turn this club around. Right now, the only positive is that he isn't called Glazer, and even that is wearing thin.

The 73-year-old has to get his next big decision right, but first he is opting for a dose of nostalgia. Fletcher and Jonny Evans were reunited in the dugout at Turf Moor and both got chants from the away end in the early stages. So did Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick, who are competing for the caretaker job until the end of the season.

Solskjaer's song came first. Maybe the Norwegian benefits from having a couple of tunes that go down well in United away ends. He would have liked seeing Fletcher line this side up in a 4-2-3-1, a shape Solskjaer played regularly during his time in charge.

He wouldn't have liked seeing another sloppy start. Burnley hadn't led a game since November 8, but they were ahead after 13 minutes. Casemiro was culpable for allowing Bashir Humphreys to run past him, before Ayden Heaven's closed body position saw him deflect the cross rather than block it, sending it spiralling over Senne Lammens and into the corner of the net.

Fletcher shook his head in the technical area. He had demanded to see a United team in his image and that the fans could be proud of, but this was a passive start and Burnley were picking holes around a tired Casemiro.

Fletcher's angst only increased when Lisandro Martinez had a goal ludicrously disallowed for a foul on Kyle Walker from a corner, despite both players grappling with each other, but it came at a time when his team were beginning to hit their stride.

Matheus Cunha had a header cleared off the line and the best of Sesko's three shots on target before the break was an excellent header that forced Dubravka into an acrobatic save. Patrick Dorgu suffered the same fate as Cunha, dinking a finish over Dubravka after a slick team move, only to see his effort hacked away from under his own crossbar by Maxime Esteve.

Dorgu had looked lively down the left, with Cunha starting on the right as Fletcher opted for natural wingers. They both played narrow, however, and United's attacks rarely stretched beyond the edges of the penalty box. Sesko was fed a diet of crosses from deep, connecting with deliveries from Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro, but in areas where it was difficult to score.

It made the importance of getting the final ball right all the more important, so it's a good job Fernandes was back in the side. He showed supreme vision to thread a pass through a packed defence for the much-improved Sesko, who timed his run well and slammed a first-time finish home in front of the United fans.

United had control of the game now. Fernandes drilled a half-volley against the post from an angle and Heaven somehow headed a corner wide from three yards. It looked a matter of time until they scored again and it was no surprise it was Sesko again. Dorgu's cross was superb but the striker's controlled right-footed volley was just as good.

That should have been that, but Fletcher will know by now that nothing comes easy in this job. Burnley levelled out of nowhere, Lisandro Martinez too passive in allowing Jaidon Anthony time to turn and deliver a brilliant curling finish in the penalty area.

Sesko tested Dubravka twice more as United sought the winner they deserved. Fletcher showed his faith in youth by sending Lacey on for Manuel Ugarte and nearly got his reward. The teenager smashed a shot against the bar and drilled another just wide, but it wasn't to be for his Under-18s boss.

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's Man United transfer verdict could spell great news for one player
body: The potential appointment of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer as interim manager at Manchester United could be good news for Kobbie Mainoo, with Solskjaer making his feelings clear on one of the club's transfer decisions since his own exit.

United have held talks with the Norwegian about potentially taking over as interim boss until the end of the season. The club are on the lookout for a new manager after the sacking of Ruben Amorim earlier this week.

Solskjaer is currently out of work after leaving Turkish side Besiktas in the summer. Any appointment at United will see him return to the place where he managed between November 2019 and November 2021.
Midfielder Scott McTominay was a regular under the manager, but fell out of favour after his exit. He completed a move to Italian side Napoli in 2024 and has since gone from strength to strength.
Speaking to the BBC back in May, Solskjaer said: "Scott and Fred together, they were lads you would put your hat on every day to give 100%.
"How you can sell Scott is beyond me."

McTominay’s situation at United somewhat mirrors the current one of Mainoo. Napoli have been linked with an interest in the England international in the current window, but the managerial situation could change things.
Mainoo has struggled for game time under Amorim, but Solskjaer's stance on the sale of McTominay hints that he may be given more of a chance if the former striker is appointed as interim manager.

If he is given more game time, then Mainoo will hope to show that he can get back to the levels that saw him play a crucial part in United's FA Cup win in 2024 and England's run to the Euros final the next summer. If so, he could potentially earn himself a recall to the England squad for the summer's World Cup.
It's not just Mainoo who could benefit; in the same interview, Solskjaer was full of praise for defender Harry Maguire, who he brought to the club from Leicester City in 2019.
"For me, Harry has always been a leader and a fighter," he said. "I was never in doubt when I signed him and he walked in the door he would be captain for us."
Maguire has missed nine recent Premier League games through injury, but was back on the bench for Wednesday night’s 2-2 draw with Burnley at Turf Moor.

In coming in until the end of the season, Solkjaer will be managing both players that he has previously worked with at United and ones that he hasn’t. That’s something that is likely to be a challenge.
"Look, recruitment is probably the most important thing in football,” he again said back in May. "You need the structures right and you need to get the right people in.

"When you manage two, three, four or five different managers' players, it is hard to make it balance into a team you want to see. Everyone knows you need continuity and patience to get success, but not too many get it."
He has, however, made his stance on United perfectly clear. "Man United is my family and will always be part of me," he added.
"In football, you don't feel sorry for anyone because we are privileged, absolutely 100% privileged to be able to work in clubs like this.
"But for me, it is hard to watch because it is your family that is struggling. It is never easy at the weekend when you look at the table."

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United make decision on head coach for Brighton FA Cup tie
body: Manchester United have asked Darren Fletcher to stay on as caretaker head coach for Sunday's FA Cup tie with Brighton at Old Trafford. United are set to continue talks with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick over stepping into an interim role until the end of the season over the next two days, but Fletcher will take charge of the clash with the Seagulls.

The Scot oversaw United's 2-2 draw with Burnley at Turf Moor on Wednesday night and has been told by chief executive Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox that he will remain in charge for the game on Sunday. "They would like me to take the team for Sunday," Fletcher said of his discussions with Wilcox and Berrada.
"There was a feeling that might have been the case from Monday but we wanted to focus on Burnley but, yeah, I'm tasked with leading the team on Sunday so all my focus and energy goes to that now."

Fletcher was happy with how the players responded to a tumultuous few days at Burnley, despite seeing his side held in East Lancashire. United racked up 30 shots to Burnley's seven and should have won.

"I thought they put in a performance that should win the match. I think they created a lot of chances. I think they had 30 shots, goal line clearances, disallowed goal for, I'm not sure why," said Fletcher.

"So if you look at it in that context, in terms of the shots and the domination that we had in the game, we should win the match, so I'm pleased with that. There was lots of good things, it wasn't perfect. I thought we started slow.

"We improved as the first half went on and I actually challenged the players at half-time. I think they had more levels in them and I think they produced that at the start of the second half and scored two fantastic goals.
"Still lots to work on but I was really pleased with their efforts and how they tried to implement what we'd asked for them with very limited time to prepare."
